page.title: 02Birth of Newton Aycliffe
page.content: At the onset of{World War 2}accessible sites,sufficiently uninhabited and suitable for{armaments factories}were} desperately needed. One site lay in the rural area of Great Aycliffe,known as{Simpasture.}It was sprinkled with only a handful of farms,cottages and a wooden Methodist chapel. 16,000 workers,mainly women travelled large distances daily,until the factory closed at the end of the war in 1945. The site was taken over by North East Trading Estates Ltd.Its strategic position attracted{industry}and by 1951,seventy firms employed 3000 workers.The birth of{Newton Aycliffe was directed by Aycliffe Development Corporation chaired by{Lord Beveridge. In 1956{town and trading estate became {one,}when a road was made under the railway line.Population 1985 _26,000.
